subject: The Bizarro GRRM
event:
My friend Janice Gelb sent me this great link from The Onion. 

http://www.theonion.com/content/node/52915

Can this be Bizarro George?

comments.upictitle: Stop drooling at my pic!!!!: Author pose
comments.article: I have not read him personally but it would be very cool if he turned it on its head making it a science fiction book that they all drank the elixer of life and were immortal. It would really confuse the hell out of the people who read the first two books, although I doubt the critics would like it.
It could be called "Red Mars".

comments.upictitle: [not pictured]: meta Safiiru moodless collected nerdy
comments.article: That is totally the first thing I thought of when I saw that article.
Same here. We're such dorks.
Looks like you in reverse. Not that I really have anything interesting to say about it, but I can't let this chance slip to be the very first to comment.
Damn, and even that little thing is taken from me!

I'm sure there is -still- a dent in the wall in my old apartment from what I will only refer to as, "The Robb Incident."

*shakes fist*

You sir, are no Pussy.

;o)

*snigger*

I was sitting reading that bit in Paddington station and nearly had my bag stolen without noticing (someone else noticed and stopped the thief) because I was staring through the page in shock!
He can't drop the hammer.
comments.subject: This dude has a bad case of "Minnesota Nice"!

comments.article: I'm surprised you've taken this so calmly. I mean, once you've made it into the Onion, how can your writing career possibly rise any further? :/
The Daily Show/Colbert Report?

hehehe - bizarro you!

he never kills characters, and you kill too many...

you kill them even when they are still alive... he manages to keep alive the dead ones...

actually, i think he is your equal and opposite force. Yellow, to your Green Latern.
Don't puss out!  Stay strong and reap where you will!
Haha, two thumbs up.

I don't like BG 'spoits either.

/cross LJ recognition.

comments.upictitle: Life's a beach. Not littorally, of course: digger
comments.article: Ah, I still remember fondly my friend's text message of a few years ago, typed all in capitals to properly convey his utter outrage, "THEY KILLED ROB STARK!" Still have a bet on with him whether even you will kill Dany off in some random and futile way before even getting her to Westeros...

Blah. Why did so many people care so much about Robb Stark anyways?

1) He's an oathbreaker. Walder Frey had every right to be mad.

2) He doesn't tell Edmure that he's hoping to ambush Tywin. I guess informing your chief bannerman about your battleplans isn't important?

3) He murdered Rickard Karstark. This guy lost all his heirs in Robb's little revenge-minded crusade. He didn't deserve that.

4) The whole "king in the North" thing. Good job ensuring future civil wars and not coordinating with Stannis to keep Tywin away from King's Landing during the invasion, buddy.

Ha. When I think of how the only time I've /ever/ involuntarily cried out "No!" upon reading a book (or for that matter, at any time) was when Theon was shown displaying what appeared to be Bran's body...

(And I think I did it again when Sandor Clegane threw the axe at Arya. You've made me lose my book-reading dignity twice, Mr. Martin.)
I only remember crying YESSS! when Catelyn died and NOOO! when she appeared again :O That woman was/is annoying :P
Haha, this is exactly what made me love your work. After "that" pivotal scene in Game of Thrones, I was hooked. Thanks for being different, heh. ^^/
Ha. Yes, Ned's fate hooked me, and Robb's repeated the trick. I now want to get my own work published, purely so that I can make others suffer as I have suffered. It's only fair.

Hee! As long as Tyrion sees it through to the end of the tale I will have no quarrel with you George. Although this is mainly because I have spent a great deal of time convincing myself Davos isn't dead in spite of what's hinted in "Feast".
While on the subject of deaths in ASOI&F I will never forget the loud expletive riddled statement from my sister when you bought Catelyn back at the end of "Storm".
Finally if you would be so kind as to bring Sandor in as a pov character in a later book despite the fact we last saw him carking out under a tree I will buy you a pony.

comments.upictitle: Thoughts of a nerdy feminist: pic#124268277
comments.article: Tyrion and Jaime. I can't believe I was made to like him.

comments.subject: As long as we're listing the characters we like...

comments.upictitle: Popular series of fiction, fancy, and fact.: Benevolent sense of life
comments.article:
I have been somewhat alarmed by the high mortality rate of your primary characters. At the current rate, you'll be out of POV figures halfway through the next book, forcing you to start importing Piers Anthony protagonists just in order to kill them off.

Perhaps SoFI characters can be declared an endangered species?

comments.upictitle: The Fourth Horsefrog of the Apocalypse: eye
comments.article: I'm not entirely sure killing off Piers Anthony characters is a bad idea....

comments.upictitle: Thoughts of a nerdy feminist: pic#124268277
comments.article:
Sadly, I fear this guy resembles me a little. I'm trying to learn to murder my darlings, I SWEAR!

I've been really entertained by an lj friend of mine who was reading your books for the first time and writing about her reactions. The most amusing posts by far were the ones in red, all capital letters screaming that you did NOT, did NOT just kill Eddard Stark! I think she'd gotten a little bit desensitized by the time she came around to the Red Wedding.

HA! That's great. Even more amusingly, the page loaded with an advertismement for a mp3 player that seems to be named the Sansa e200. I'm sure it wasn't intentional, but still, that's a hell of a coincidence!

comments.upictitle: in search of a clever byline: ETC - Vonnegut
comments.article:
yeah...that's what i find completely tops the bizzaro element. the logo's even wolf-like.

heh

I'm still a little sad that you killed off Pod.

But what is potential in your books but something to crush before it blossoms.

Don't mind me, I just finished "Portraits of His Children" and found it worse then anything in The Song of Fire and Ice.

Hurr...

comments.upictitle: Xray Is As Xray Does: horns
comments.article: You've friends in lofty places! First the off-hand comment about Westeros, and now a mini-profile of your bizarro counterpart! When they give you a guest spot on the Horoscopes page, you know you'll be set for the remainder of your publishing career! (Taurus: This week you will be offered a crown in place of your horned helm. Move cautiously, for a Lannister has it in for you.)

Haha! As much as I get angry with you when I'm actually reading, the fact that no one is safe means I have absolutely no idea what's coming, which is fantastic. I mean, I know how the characters WANT things to end... but nothing is sacred, which is amazing. But also frightening.

In other words: don't ever, EVER be ANYTHING like that!!

For me, it's that some people die, and some people come back.. so I spend the remaining chapters wondering if you really did it. I like that it keeps me on my toes.

However, do you have any idea how hard it is NOT to flip forward and look at the remaining chapter titles????
comments.subject: heh heh

comments.upictitle: Thoughts of a nerdy feminist: pic#124268277
comments.article: I do that. *hangs head*
comments.subject: Re: heh heh

comments.article:
The only thing I can say about your killing off characters is this: I like the Starks too much to see any more of them die. Although it is cool how Caitlyn seems to have a cat's 9 lives.

And yes, I'm hoping a few of the other marquee characters are removed from the story, I'll just not say who since knowing my luck they'd be given enough armor to make a tank jealous.
of course cat is a tully and not a stark by blood

That article was hilarious!

*tries to imagine what ASOIAF would be like if nobody died*

*brain hurts*

Granted, change is an essential part of any good story. Death is just an extreme change. Every time I re-read ASOIAF, I keep thinking of a production I saw of King Lear once, with bodies strewn across the stage, as the characters died one by one. And then one fellow pipes up:

CAPTAIN: Edmund is dead, my lord.
ALBANY: That's but a trifle here

The audience cracked up at that moment, even though the play is a tragedy.

i stand by my belief that shakespeare wrote comedies. well, comi-tragidies maybe. when they made the big-production movie of Hamlet, my dad and i went and saw it. he and i were the only people in the theater laughing.

shakespeare's plays have so much irony and dry wit in them (like your example) that i find them truly funny, and enjoy them much more than low-brow, slapstick humor.

Nope, you don't have to worry about an attack from your Bizarro self, George! I just finished Storm of Swords, and it took more than two hands worth of fingers to count the number of characters described in the Appendix who were dead by the time that novel ended. Bastard! Will anyone of note be alive in Westeros by the time the saga ends?

Marvelous books, by the way. Blew literally almost half of last week with Storm of Swords as I could not put that damned book down! I describe the saga to my friends as "The Lord of the Rings meets 24," and that description has prompted at least two of them to buy Game of Thrones and see what all the fuss was about. :)

The booze and cold in Minnesota makes us live forever - preservatives ya know. Why else would we live here? ;)

P.S. What is Pod never dies, but rises stronger!! *fangirls*
